skill.name: skill-from-masters
skill.description: Help users create high-quality skills by discovering and incorporating proven methodologies from domain experts. Use this skill BEFORE skill-creator when users want to create a new skill - it enhances skill-creator by first identifying expert frameworks and best practices to incorporate. Triggers on requests like "help me create a skill for X" or "I want to make a skill that does Y". This skill guides methodology selection, then hands off to skill-creator for the actual skill generation.
skill.summary: Help users create high-quality skills by discovering and incorporating proven methodologies from dom...
skill.author: GBSOSS

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill with no executable code, no filesystem access beyond its own reference file, no network calls, and no command execution capabilities. All described functionality (web searches) is handled by the AI platform's built-in search tools.

content.value_statement: Creating skills from scratch often misses proven frameworks from domain experts. This skill researches and synthesizes methodologies from recognized masters so your final skill embodies the highest level of human expertise.
actual_capabilities: Searches local database of expert methodologies
Performs 3-layer web research to find relevant frameworks
Synthesizes insights from multiple expert sources
Identifies golden examples and common pitfalls
Guides collaborative methodology selection with users
limitations: Does not generate the final skill code itself
Requires skill-creator skill for actual skill generation
Search quality depends on web source availability
Methodology database covers major domains but not all

use_cases.title: Create PRD skills
use_cases.description: Build skills for writing product requirement documents using Amazon's working backwards and Marty Cagan's problem-first frameworks

use_cases.title: Develop documentation skills
use_cases.description: Create skills for technical documentation using William Zinsser's simplicity principles and Barbara Minto's pyramid structure

use_cases.title: Build writing skills
use_cases.description: Develop persuasive writing skills based on Eugene Schwartz's awareness levels and David Ogilvy's headline frameworks

prompt_templates.title: Basic skill request
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me create a skill for [task or domain]. I want it to incorporate expert methodologies.

prompt_templates.title: Specific methodology
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to build a skill for [skill type]. Find the best expert frameworks and methodologies for [specific domain].

prompt_templates.title: Multi-methodology blend
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me create a skill for [skill type] that combines [expert A]'s methodology with [expert B]'s framework. Research both and identify how they work together.

prompt_templates.title: Deep synthesis
prompt_templates.prompt: Find and synthesize 3-5 expert methodologies for [skill type]. Include core principles, implementation steps, quality criteria, and common mistakes to avoid. Cross-validate across sources.

output_examples.input: Help me create a skill for writing sales emails
output: Expert frameworks identified: Eugene Schwartz (5 Levels of Awareness), Gary Halbert (AIDA + Proof), Neil Rackham (SPIN Selling)
Key insight: Match email complexity to prospect awareness level
Quality criteria: Subject line clarity, value proposition in first paragraph, specific call to action
Common mistake: Starting with features instead of prospect problems
Recommended: Combine Schwartz awareness mapping with Halbert's proof stacking for maximum impact

best_practices: Use the 3-layer search approach: local database first, then web search, then deep-dive primary sources
Always cross-validate findings across multiple experts to identify high-confidence principles
Distill methodologies into specific, actionable steps rather than vague principles
anti_patterns: Skipping the research phase and relying only on the local database
Ignoring conflicts between methodologies without resolving or flagging them
Using only secondary summaries instead of fetching primary source material

faq.question: What does this skill actually do?
faq.answer: It researches and recommends expert methodologies for your skill idea. It does not write code or create the final skill.

faq.question: How is this different from skill-creator?
faq.answer: skill-from-masters prepares the methodology foundation. skill-creator generates the actual skill file with instructions and examples.

faq.question: Does this skill make network calls?
faq.answer: No. The skill uses platform search tools. No code in the skill makes network requests or accesses external systems.

faq.question: What domains does the database cover?
faq.answer: Major domains including writing, product management, sales, leadership, engineering, startups, productivity, negotiation, and finance.

faq.question: How many methodologies should I use?
faq.answer: The workflow recommends selecting 1-3 primary methodologies. Too many creates conflicting guidance. Combine only when complementary.

faq.question: Can I add my own methodology?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill supports custom methodology research. You can request it search for specific experts or frameworks not in the database.
